contentrichtext.text: {{otherpeople}} [[Image:Carymap.jpg|thumb|right|300px|''A New Map of the British Isles, from the Latest Authorities 1807'', from John Cary's world atlas]] '''John Cary''' (c. 1754 – 1835) was an [[England|English]] [[cartographer]]. Cary served his apprenticeship as an engraver in London, before setting up his own business in the Strand in 1783. He soon gained a reputation for his maps and globes, his [[atlas (cartography)|atlas]], ''The New and Correct English Atlas'' published in 1787, becoming a standard reference work in England. In 1794 Cary was commissioned by the [[United Kingdom Postmaster General|Postmaster General]] to survey England's roads. This resulted in ''Cary's New Itinerary'' (1798), a map of all the major roads in England and [[Wales]]. He also produced [[Ordnance Survey]] maps prior to 1805. In his later life he collaborated on geological maps with the geologist [[William Smith (geologist)|William Smith]].<ref>David Smith, ‘Cary, John (1755–1835)’, rev., Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004</ref> His business was eventually taken over by G. F. Cruchley (1822–1875). Cary's major works include: *''Actual Survey of the country fifteen miles around London'' (1786) *''New and Correct English Atlas'' (1787) *''Camden's Britannia'' (1789) - maps for 1789 and 1806 editions *''Cary's Survey of the High Roads from London'' (1790) *''Cary's Traveller's Companion'' (1790) *''New Maps of England and Wales with part of Scotland'' (1794) *''Inland Navigation; or Select Plans of the Several Navigable Canals throughout Britain'' (1795) *''Cary's New Itinerary'' (1798) *''New British Atlas'' (1805), with John Stockdale *''Cary's New Universal Atlas'' (1808) *''Cary's English Atlas'' (1809) *''New Elementary Atlas'' (1813) *''[http://www.maproom.org/00/18/index.php Cary's New Itinerary]'' (1817) ==External links== *[http://www.mostlymaps.com/reference/Map-Makers/john-carey.php Brief biography at Mostly Maps] *[http://www.kunstpedia.com/articles/457/1/George-Frederick-Cruchley-1796-1880/Page1.html George Frederick Cruchley 1796-1880] ==References== {{Commons category}} {{reflist}} *Allen, P.
